author: onqtam
content:
Has anyone ever proposed mapping addresses to indexes? For example all new transactions after block X (some upgrade) could be checked if a mapping exists and if the to/from addresses don't have an address=>ID mapping - such could be generated (with an auto incrementing global counter) and stored in the state on-the-fly. Then for subsequent transactions involving those addresses the unique indexes from the mapping can be used ==> reducing the bytes required to describe a transaction ==> reducing the block size & chain growth & network bandwidth. This means that there would be 2 ways to encode transactions and this can be done either gradually (as explained here) or perhaps all nodes can scan and map all addresses to indexes as a batch job in preparation for block X in the future after which the new encoding would be allowed. This could also be applied to the r & s components of the ECDSA signatures if those don't change as well for a particular user (not familiar with that part of crypto).

I haven't done any calculations but it seems to me that for simple transactions that don't have big inputs (simple transfers) this could save maybe about ~50% of the size, and I think the biggest thing in blocks is the list of transactions...?

Currently in order for me to check my balance I need to send requests to a full node anyway so in the future the translation of indexes to actual hashes/addresses/keys shouldn't be much of a problem as well.

Thoughts? Is this worth investigating & drafting a proposal in ethresear.ch or has this obvious idea been rejected in the past?
